Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Improving and Understanding the Catalysts used to Convert Biological Oils to Diesel Fuel
Award.AbstractNarration:
Biodiesel constitutes the major renewable fuel derived from lipid-based feedstocks such as vegetable oils and animal fats; however, several issues hinder biodiesel from being completely fungible with traditional petroleum diesel. Biodiesel?s poor cold flow properties, storage stability, and engine compatibility problems stem from its oxygen content. Recently, attention has been shifted to develop a process for the removal of oxygen from lipid-based feedstocks to generate a renewable fuel that is chemically identical to petroleum derived fuels. The award will help investigate unique catalysts that are vital to this process by sending a graduate student, currently working at the University of Kentucky Center for Applied Energy Research (CAER), to the Centre of Excellence for Functional Nanomaterials of the University of Queensland (UQ) in Brisbane, Australia. The graduate student will work with the group of Dr. Jorge Beltramini at UQ to harness the materials, know-how and instrumentation available there to develop and understand new catalysts for the conversion of biological oils to diesel fuel.

Ni-based catalysts are attracting attention as some of the most promising formulations for the conversion of lipid-based feedstocks to fuel-like hydrocarbons. Nevertheless, important gaps in the fundamental understanding of several aspects of these catalysts remain, including the effect of the support porosity and morphology, catalyst preparation method, and the chemical and electronic state of both Ni and Ni promoters on the performance of these formulations. The project will include: 1) the synthesis of unique mesoporous supports; 2) the preparation of Ni-based catalysts using these supports via different methods; 3) the spectroscopic study of promoted and unpromoted catalysts to acquire basic knowledge of great importance and wide applicability for catalysis science and technology. Upon returning to the United States, not only will new know-how on synthetic techniques be available at CAER, but the catalysts synthesized at UQ will be screened for their ability to convert lipid feeds stocks to fuel-like hydrocarbons.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Australian Academy of Science.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ni-based catalysts have attracted attention as viable formulations in converting animal fats and plant oils into mixtures of hydrocarbons that are chemically identical to petroleum derived fuels. Nevertheless, many improvements and fundamental understanding of the catalysts are needed if economic scalability is to be achieved. The catalysts mentioned above are composed of an active metal, or combination of metals, that are kept in the form of microscopic particles with the use of a support. Researchers have found that different supports for these catalysts impact the overall catalytic activity in converting animal fats and plant oils into fuels. However, the effect of the support shape or “morphology” has not been thoroughly investigated.  Another aspect of interest is the preparation method of the catalyst and the resulting effect on the catalytic activity. Therefore, this work aimed to synthesize alumina supports of different morphologies, preparing catalysts using these supports via impregnation and microemulsion methods, and testing these catalysts in their ability to converts fats and oils to fuels.

The work was conducted with the assistance of Dr. Jorge Beltramini at the Centre of Excellence for Functional Nanomaterials at the University of Queensland in Queensland, Australia. Dr. Beltramini’s group has experience in synthesizing a variety of supports, microemulsion syntheses, as well as access to unique techniques to analyze these materials. With his guidance, alumina nanofiber supports were synthesized and analyzed through transmission electron microscopy, and catalysts were prepared via both the impregnation and microemulsion methods. Upon returning to the University of Kentucky for further testing, the alumina nanofiber supports were found to have a significant increase in surface area and pore sizes compared to commercially available alumina, which is noteworthy since similar increase have observed to result in improved catalytic performance in other processes. However, testing the performance for these catalysts have proven to be challenging, as determining whether the novel catalysts display improved catalytic activity requires testing using a set of experimental conditions in which intermediate conversion of the starting material is achieved. Indeed, conditions resulting in either scant or complete conversion of the starting material afford little information about effect that changes in the structure of different catalysts have on performance. Nevertheless, considerable progress has been made to identify the right set of testing conditions to assess the catalytic performance of these new materials.

Overall, the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes (EAPSI) program provided a unique opportunity for a graduate student to obtain training and conduct research abroad, all while establishing an international collaboration. Know-how regarding sophisticated techniques for catalyst synthesis was brought back to the United States and will be applied to variety of other projects and taught to students at both the graduate and undergraduate level. The program allowed for unique cultural exchanges with both the Aboriginal and Australian people, these experiences being shared with students in the United States to highlight the unique opportunities available to individuals pursuing a career in science. Few programs compare to EAPSI in providing such edifying scientific and cultural experiences to young scientists.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 03/14/2017
Modified by: Ryan A Loe
